page.title: 08NEWDIGATE RIGHTS OF WAY
page.content: There are approximately twelve defined Rights of Way in the specified grids and many other footpaths.These generally connect places of importance,i.e.Farms,Church,School and Public Houses.They have all been walked recently and most stiles and footbridges are in good condition. Nowadays footpaths are mainly walked for pleasure by local people and rambling groups.The paths are the responsibility of the local landowner but help with maintenance can be obtained from the local authority.All paths are marked with a finger post where they meet the highway and many are marked with yellow waymarks for footpaths or blue waymarks for bridleways.Most paths have been in existance for hundreds of years and their route cannot be altered except by an order from the local authority.
